thread.title: UK credit rating still at risk over disorderly Brexit, say agencies

title: UK credit rating still at risk over disorderly Brexit, say agencies
text:
April 27, 2018 / 9:00 PM / Updated 8 hours ago UK credit rating still at risk over disorderly Brexit, say agencies Reuters Staff 2 Min Read
LONDON (Reuters) - Britain’s credit ratings are still at risk from Brexit, Standard & Poor’s Global Ratings and Fitch both said on Friday, keeping existing ‘negative outlook’ warnings in place in their latest assessments of the country’s creditworthiness. FILE PHOTO: The Canary Wharf financial district is seen at dusk in London, Britain, November 17, 2017. Picture taken November 17, 2017. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo
Britain’s economy held up better than most forecasters expected at the time of the June 2016 Brexit vote to leave the European Union, although figures published on Friday showed it began 2018 on a weak footing, due in part to heavy snowfalls.
Nevertheless, Brexit dominated the rating agencies’ assessments, with S&P leaving its AA rating for Britain unchanged but warning that uncertainty over its future relationship with the EU persisted.
“We could lower the ratings if we view the risk of a disorderly Brexit as increasingly certain,” S&P said.
“We could revise the outlook to stable if negotiations with the EU move with greater certainty for the U.K., and if key sectors retain access to European markets without penalizing tariffs.”
S&P stripped Britain of its top-notch AAA rating shortly after the 2016 referendum decision.
Britain has negotiated a transition agreement with the European Union which means little will change for firms immediately after Brexit. It has also begun negotiating the terms of the future trading relations that will come into force after December 2020.
Fitch said its negative outlook reflected “continued, albeit reduced, downside risks of an acrimonious and disruptive exit from EU”. The agency also rates Britain at AA.
Earlier this week, official data showed Britain recorded its smallest budget deficit, as a share of economic output, in 16 years in the 2017/18 financial year. Reporting by William James; Editing by Catherine Evans
